Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Geography of Stop and Frisk in Nine U.S. Cities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Police agencies across the United States employ stop and frisk practices as part of a proactive crime-fighting strategy. These tactics are criticized because they disproportionately implicate Black and Latinx individuals, tend to be concentrated in poor neighborhoods of color, and sometimes involve the detainment of people who are never arrested. However, existing social science scholarship does not adequately address why some neighborhoods experience more stop and frisk activity than others. Moreover, it fails to consider the ways that geographic variation in proactive policing are related to legal decision-making. This is an important question because legal scholars argue that developments in Fourth Amendment jurisprudence have resulted in a threshold for conducting stops that is lower in poor, minority neighborhoods than in Whiter, more affluent areas. The present research seeks to address these gaps by: (1) examining which social processes generate geographic variation in stop and frisk across census tracts and identifying characteristics of "surveillance hotspots," and (2) investigating whether the legal standards for justifying stops are relaxed in perceived "high-crime" areas. This study will broaden understanding of inequality in the criminal justice system by exploring the roots of these inequalities.

To achieve these aims, the researcher combines three types of data to analyze these relationships, including: (1) pedestrian stop and frisk incidents, (2) crime incidents, and (3) demographic data from the Census and American Community Survey. Stage one will utilize data from nine cities across the United States (Austin, Boston, Chicago, Denver, New Orleans, New York City, Philadelphia, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C.) to identify the neighborhood characteristics and social processes associated with "surveillance hotspots"--those areas that experience exceptionally high concentrations of stop and frisk activity. Analyses for this stage consist of estimating fixed-effects ordinary least squares and geographically weighted regression models. The second stage draws on detailed information about the bases for pedestrian stops in two cities (Chicago and New York City) to evaluate whether the legal thresholds for conducting stops systematically varies across census tracts. Analyses for stage two involve estimating spatial regression models to evaluate neighborhood-level variation in legal thresholds for making stops by analyzing the relationships between neighborhood marginality, reasonable suspicion justifications, and arrest rates. The findings from this study will shed light on the macro-level social processes that lead to inequitable policing and could be utilized by law enforcement agencies to develop practices that enhance police-community relations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of our nation’s most urgent social concerns is the coercive and disproportionate policing of economically disadvantaged Black and Latinx communities and the spaces in which they live. Although racially disparate outcomes in policing are well documented, the mechanisms driving geographically inequitable policing remain obscured. In an attempt to fill this intellectual fissure and cultivate knowledge that can inform public policy, this dissertation addresses the following questions. First, what neighborhood social processes are associated with the development of “surveillance hot spots” – areas that experience exceptionally high concentrations of stop and frisk activity? How and why do these patterns differ across cities? Second, guided by the theoretical work of legal scholars, I ask, is the law of policing practiced differently in the most marginalized neighborhoods? Financial support provided by an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant funded travel costs that permitted me to attend two statistics and methodological workshops. These workshops outfitted me with the skills necessary to work with and analyze spatial, administrative data properly.

 To quantitatively address these questions, I collected and combined three types of data: police pedestrian stops, UCR type 1 crime incidents, and demographic information from the U.S. Census Bureau. Data from the following cities were analyzed: Austin, Boston, Chicago, Denver, New Orleans, New York City, Philadelphia, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. The results reveal a complex set of findings with relationships differing widely across cities, suggesting that geographic patterns in pedestrian police stops are, in part, a function of the local context. While geographic patterns of policing in some cities appeared explicitly racialized, in others, they seemed to be driven by neighborhood change, notably gentrification. However, further analysis revealed that gentrification processes are also racialized, such that policing of gentrified areas also negatively impacts Black and Latinx communities.

Findings from a second set of analyses, using data from Chicago, indicate that the law is implemented differently in neighborhoods that are economically and racially marginalized. As hypothesized, greater subjectivity is used to justify police stops in neighborhoods with more concentrated disadvantage, more crime, and that possess greater proportions of Black and Latinx residents. This exercise of officer discretion is not justified by stop outcomes, as relatively fewer stops in marginalized neighborhoods result in enforcement action.

 This project exhibits intellectual merit through its theoretical and methodological insights into the sociological study of inequitable policing. Racialized policing has traditionally been understood as a product of racial and ethnic threat. While this study supports these perspectives, it also suggests that the racialized nature of policing is tied up with processes of urban change, particularly gentrification. Consequently, sociologists must reconsider what is considered a social threat in the twenty-first century. In particular, we must pay more attention to notions of territoriality and entitlement to urban spaces, and the role that police play in race- and class-based segregation of these spaces. My findings suggest that marginalized neighborhoods are policed with a greater degree of subjectivity, a pattern permitted, if not encouraged, by the law. This should prompt sociologists to question the fundamental “neutrality” or “objectivity” of the law. Rather than continuing to rely on legally-based standards, such as constitutionality, to determine whether disparities exist, I encourage researchers to build on this work and think about more ways that the law is fundamentally unequal.

I have already begun implementing the broader impacts of this project through the dissemination of research findings. A subset of this project was presented as part of a panel on policing and racial threat at the 2019 Annual Meeting of the American Society of Criminology in San Francisco, CA. The full manuscript of the resulting dissertation will be archived in the University of Miami Scholarly Repository, which is available to the public. I am currently completing an article based on the project findings, which will be submitted for publication in a peer-review outlet.  Furthermore, this project yielded meaningful insights that will be of interest to law enforcement and local government officials who wish to address problems related to racially inequitable policing and mistrust of police within Black and Latinx communities.
